subject: Re: How to comment test methods in Junit 4?
msgSnippet: Dear Kent, Thanks for your reply, this filter example is exactly what I am looking for and it solved my problem. Thanks again for your valuable suggestion.
messageBody:
Dear Kent,

Thanks for your reply, this filter example is exactly what I am
looking for and it solved my problem.
Thanks again for your valuable suggestion.

Thanks,
vgreddy.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Dear VGReddy,
>
> The new filter support gives you programmable control over what
tests are
> run. For example:
>
> public class FilterTest {
> public static class Example {
> @Test public void one() {}
> @Test public void two() {}
> @Test public void three() {}
> }
>
> @Test public void filter() {
> Request request= Request.aClass(Example.class);
> Filter filter= new Filter() {
> @Override
> public boolean shouldRun(Description
description) {
> return
> description.getDisplayName().startsWith("t");
> }
>
> @Override
> public String describe() {
> throw new
UnsupportedOperationException();
> }
> };
> Request filtered= request.filterWith(filter);
> Result result= new JUnitCore().run(filtered);
> assertEquals(2, result.getRunCount());
> }
> }
>
> It seems to me like this will solve your problem, although it may
be too
> general for your purposes.
>
> Sincerely yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of vgreddy43
> > Sent: Tuesday, May 30, 2006 6:20 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Re: How to comment test methods in Junit 4?
> >
> > Can anybody help me on how to solve this?
> >
> > Thanks.
> >
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "vgreddy43" <vgreddy43@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello friends,
> > >
> > > I have a test case with some testmethods which are written in
> > > junit 4 style. As showsn below.
> > >
> > > public Class MyTestCase{
> > >
> > > @Before
> > > public void mysetup(){
> > > //some code
> > > }
> > >
> > > @Test
> > > public void mytest1(){
> > > //some code
> > > }
> > >
> > > @Test
> > > public void mytest2(){
> > > //some code
> > > }
> > >
> > > @After
> > >
> > > public void myteardown(){
> > > //some code
> > > }
> > >
> > > public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
> > > return new JUnit4TestAdapter(MyTestCase.class);
> > > }
> > >
> > > When we run this it will test mytest1 and mytest2 methods.
> > > But if I want only mytest1 to run how do I do that. Using
@Ignore
> > we
> > > can comment other tests but I want to do this in junit3.8
style,
> > like
> > >
> > > Public static Test suite() {
> > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("TestSuite");
> > > suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("mytest1"));
> > > //suite.addTest(new OIDBHelperTest("myttest2"));
> > > //suite.addTest(new OIDBHelperTest("myttest3"));
> > >
> > > return suite;
> > > }
> > >
> > > Any ideas on this, how to acheive this type of functionality
in
> > > junit4?
> > >
> > > thanks.
>
